alternatives.transcript: boom boom
welcome to Little Rock now your program about your concerns let's join Linda Gilliam and her guests or tonight's discussion good evening everyone and welcome once

get into our show whether you smoke or not we all know someone who smokes and they probably don't agree with our views on the subject from the tobacco industry to anti-smoking groups and yes even the government well today we're going to look at the issue of smoking from the tobacco industry side and from the American Cancer Society spokesman we have with us tonight as our guest mr. Walker merryman who is with the tobacco Institute out of Washington DC and dr. Kent Westbrook of the University of Arkansas

consol medical Sciences Center thank you gentlemen for being with us tonight I guess just for the record will start with you mr. Merriman and and just try to get a little background information on just what exactly is the tobacco Institute and what is your particular purpose well really the tobacco Institute is nothing more than a trade Association that are dozens hundreds perhaps thousands of them in the country most of them operate like we do that is in a non-commercial non-promotional way according to
Federal Charter as a nonprofit organization but we do principally two things we provide information

in the form of public relations activity we also provide information in the form of lobbying activity the federal level state level sometimes city and county level as well those are two principal functions and all of our efforts are focused in that way and have been since 1958 when we first opened our doors obviously our efforts have stepped up over the years as the activities in Congress and State legislatures and elsewhere have increased over

years okay we'll get back to you on a little more from the tobacco Institute but dr. Westbrook you are a former president of the Arkansas affiliate of the Arkansas division of the American Cancer Society and we all know of the American Cancer Society and the works that go on but for the record again give us a description of what the Cancer Society does as far as dealing with anti-smoking well the American Cancer Society is primarily a volunteer work

ization it's made up of people some of whom are professionals by that I mean some of them are Physicians most of whom are lay people the American Cancer Society also has some staff people that are employed by the American Cancer Society to accomplish its goals the goals that the American Cancer Society has in general are to educate people about cancer to render service to people that have cancer and to support research

Martin can't trim with regard to smoking in particular the American Cancer Society feels that smoking is a cause of cancer and therefore is something that they should provide information to people about okay mr. Marion you indicated that the tobacco Institute is a non-commercial nonprofit organization and it's obvious that the tobacco industry is very much a part of our economy how can that be well we have to be non-compliant

commercial in the sense of not attempting to promote any products I'm not going to try to sell cigarettes or convince anybody to start smoking it's a matter of fact it's illegal for me to sell cigarettes on your air lately is it has been for 13 years it's not the way we wanted it we wanted to go off voluntarily but Congress wouldn't allow that but we obviously do the best we can to make it as easy as possible for our member companies to enter into an operate in a market that is as free as it

and be from unnecessary restriction that is a general statement of principles is what we do along with what I described earlier and that takes lobbying takes public relations take certain number of Staff certainly fewer staff than in any of the anti-smoking organizations well who supports the group we are supporting entirely based on their share of the market by the cigarette manufacturing companies we've got a dozen members

yes and they include the very largest companies that you've all heard of and some very very small ones that probably aren't heard of at all dr. Westbrook the cancer society's nonprofit also are you as fortunate in your support efforts as far as very large companies or well yes you know the American Cancer Society to get money from lots of places and I'm sure has probably more money than the tobacco Institute although I don't really know do you know the relationship between what is it just as a matter of information

as I recall I think that the cancer society's budget outstrips the institute's by a factor of about 10 to 1 The Institute doesn't fund research the industry does whereas the Cancer Society directly funds research they've got a lot more staff people than we do but they've got more responsibilities as a matter of fact than we do as well representing more and we're focusing on and Industry whereas the cancer society's focus is I think more broadly

broad but a lot of their efforts over the years have been expended toward anti-smoking activities and now at the federal level as well for they've opened up a Washington office with some other groups which has the exclusive province of trying to promote the surgeon general's goal of a smokeless Society by the year 2000 you keep using a phrase anti-smoking groups is the tobacco Institute a pro smoking group institutes Pro freedom of choice

and since we're funded by the industry obviously that would have to lead you to believe that we're pro smoking but not to the extent of trying to coerce somebody into making a particular decision which is where I part company with a lot of the anti smokers they think they're so right that they want to coerce you into making what they believe is the correct decision I think you can make the decision yourself is a reasonably intelligent adult with information from the Cancer Society the tobacco industry wherever you want to get it

but I don't think that the government had any level as the right of the obligation to get in there and try to make that decision for you or coerce you economically in some way into making a decision okay well the Department of Health and Human Services is it's obviously obviously trying to discourage smoking and yet at the same time we hear about the another branch of our government subsidizing the tobacco industry I mean what what kind of what is that sounds like government schizophrenia it sounds like it what it what

is happening and has been happening since the late 1930s is the Department of Agriculture administering a price support program for tobacco Farmers it benefits tobacco Farmers exclusively really although the the manufacturers do get some benefit because there are assured of a fairly steady supply of high-quality tobacco leaf over the years however the program has been changed somewhat fine-tuned to meet certain

and objections of members of Congress it's a no net cost to the taxpayer program the farmers pay for it they have to set aside a certain amount of money each time they sell a pound of tobacco to make certain that this price support Loan program doesn't end up costing the treasury the federal treasury any money there have been some loan losses in the program amounting to about 60 million dollars over 40 years

but since the federal tobacco tax last year brought in 2.8 billion dollars I think it's fair to say that whatever losses have been sustained over the years or miniscule in comparison to the economic benefit that's been generated by keeping these small farmers on the farm growing tobacco and they are almost exclusively very small farmers who grow tobacco it's their bread and butter crop they couldn't get by without it they didn't have tobacco they

be able to stay on the farm and nobody really knows where they might end up but it's almost a certainty that these hundreds of thousands of small farmers who depend on Tobacco would no longer be able to be part of the Agricultural base of the echo of the national economy if they didn't have tobacco to grow that's an economical point of view are you aware of the cast of studies and switch them to marijuana and which case they wouldn't have to realize make a patch and they

could take longer vacations but you know I recognize it that cigarette tax does bring in a tremendous amount of money and a lot of good it's done in various areas from that taxed but I think that you know the use of tobacco to me or the growth of tobacco should not be determined by dollars or cents if we could if we could absolutely prove that tobacco brought in more money to the economy than it cost I still don't think that that would be the primary issue the thing that I see is a practicing

surgeon is I see people dying from cancer that I honestly believe is caused by smoking cigarettes and you can say Well everybody's got to dive something and that's true because it's George Bernard Shaw said the ultimate mortality is 1 out of 1 so it doesn't matter how you live you're ultimately going to die but I think that to see the number of people that I see dying of cancers at I honestly believe are related to cigarette smoking to me is a tragedy

Ade speaking of dollars and cents mr. Aaron what is the tobacco impact on the economy well it's fairly substantial and I think you ought to keep that in mind when you hear about things like surgeongeneral coups insistence that by the year 2000 we're going to have a smokeless Society because he hasn't told us how we're going to replace all the dollars of jobs that are going to be lost if in fact his

smoke free Society is successful within 16 very short years he's made no provision at all for trying to take care of the devastation that would occur in the economy of the southeast at least and in many states in particular Arkansas for example has about 13,000 jobs that are related directly or indirectly to the tobacco industry with a payroll of over 200 million dollars a year now I don't think that this

or any other would like to lose its economic share of tobacco's dollars and cents impact I think it's quite quite Fair as can't points out that you really shouldn't try to compare the the health controversy with the economic impact they're two separate issues that deserve their own their own discussion but on a national basis according to a study that was conducted for us by the Wharton applied Research Center at the University of Pennsylvania

tobacco accounts for about 60 billion dollars a year to the gross national product about two or two and a half percent of national private sector employment is related to The Tobacco industry and obviously every state benefits because every state has a cigarette excise tax every state has people working in tobacco wholesale and Retail and sales positions from the manufacturing standpoint so it's not something that's isolated

just to a few tobacco growing States last I heard there was tobacco grown Arkansas on one little farm up in the Northwest part of the state we are tobacco so the agricultural part of economics in Arkansas isn't terribly significant although it is there okay now there are states who impose laws and even banned cigarette smoking in public now how do those laws work how do they affect the industry and from you I'd like to know what public reaction is to those type laws

well it's a little difficult to enforce them as most communities and states have found out when they passed them sometimes there's a kind of a half-hearted effort at enforcement but very seldom is enforcement taken very seriously because it would require a great deal of resources to do that City of Chicago tried it some years ago they set aside a an entire court just for smokers who had been arrested for smoking and forbidden areas

and a lot of people went to jail overnight because they didn't have the $50 to pay for the fine and the City of Chicago finally decided that that was a pretty ridiculous way to deal with the issue and they just dropped it most cities have found that it's not practical to enforce it it's really unnecessary and it's unfair to business people who can't comply with laws like that or believe that they have complied to the extent their customers and their employees wish

any restrictions to be placed and this is really something that ought to be left up to the Democracy of the marketplace it seems to me if there's a demand for a service like this people will make that demand known as they have in some restaurants and some other places even when it imposes on other people I mean such as cigarette smoke and I have been annoyed to a point but didn't say anything because I mean I felt like well you know I guess they got too much right to be here as I have but it was annoying and I felt an imposition well you see what what has

happened in many parts of the country is that especially in restaurants for example people who run restaurants become aware because of comments by their patrons that there's a certain demand for a non-smoking area and they'll set up an area and see if it works and if it works fine if it doesn't work then they ought to have the right to change it so that they're not economically penalized by having to comply with some law or regulation and that's the way it's seem to work best in many parts of the country
okay gentlemen we'll be right back after this we need to pause now for a break we'll be right back

welcome back to Little Rock now we're here tonight with our guest mr. Walker Merriman of the tobacco Institute and dr. Kent Westbrook a former president of the American Division of the Cancer Society and he's a position with the University of Arkansas medical Sciences you had addressed the question regarding the fact that some states are now Banning are do have laws regarding smoking in public and I want

know your opinion of that those type laws well in some ways I would agree with mr. Merriman because you know there are more serious problems in our society and smoking in public and I think it would be ridiculous to send all the police in our society out to try to smoke catch people smoking in public on the other hand there are certain places I think where we absolutely have to ban smoking you know we can't have smoking in the operating room even if someone comes in and says well I'd like to smoke him here there are certain areas in the

battle where you have oxygen are there areas where you work where you have explosives that you can't have smoking but in general in public places I think that you know you have to make it for you can accommodate both smokers and non-smokers because our society still has not still has smokers in it on the other hand I would object to it you know if like on this show one of y'all wanted to light up and blow smoke in my face every time I started to say something because it would probably irritate me but I think within reason it

have to be given some choice in public places you know we have to accommodate all of society in some way or another you think there's ever a chance of cigarettes being banned doesn't such as you were talking about it by the year what 2000 to 2500 I don't think in our culture today that that's possible I think if tobacco were brand new substance that was just suddenly discovered and it had to go through the requirements that you have to go through to get certain things on the market probably it would never make it to the marketplace today

because there are a lot of things in the way of drugs and chemical additives you know that it's almost impossible to get on the market and with the scientific data we have today probably tobacco wouldn't make it but I think it's unrealistic to think that it'll ever be banned well not just for its four cigarettes in fact I've known of cases where people preferably gentleman call themselves stopping smoking by not smoking cigarettes anymore but taking up a pipe or tobacco or cigars something aren't they

hazards if there are any just as dangerous regarding you know whether it's a cigarette or cigar pipe are they less than well I would say that the scientific evidence is that the dangers are less if you don't inhale and most people that smoke a pipe or cigar don't inhale as much as people that smoke cigarettes and they're less if you have something that's low in tar and low and nicotine so I think that if one is going to smoke I think it makes a difference what you smoke and how you smoke and I

think that when you agree that the amount of exposure you get to some of the substances varies depending on what you smoke and how you smoke well I don't think there's any question about the fact that there is a difference in exposure between cigarette smokers smoke being in the atmosphere where someone is smoking I mean the amount of smoke that want to tell you I see either passively or actively directly it's a little unclear

just what the dose response relationship is but I think there is a difference what about the anti-smoking campaigns you travel a lot in your job as a spokesman for the tobacco industry since 1964 when the Surgeon General first started warning us about the hazards of smoking are the anti-smoking campaigns now still as in high gear as they were then do you see evidence of that do you Doctor well we certainly this year seen a great deal of evidence

of heightened interest on the part of the Surgeon General the Public Health Service at least doctor Koop who has made this a very specific campaign pledge of his that we have a smoke free Society by the year 2000 including Banning advertising and all sorts of other things that would have to be done by the federal government which I think is kind of ironic in this Administration that we have a Surgeon General who's a political appointee proposing all of these Federal activities to be taken

under a conservative Administration still an all I think it's probably the most activity we've seen from the public health service from the Department of Health and Human Services since about 1979 when Joe califano was Secretary of what was then H ew he was very active in his campaign as well but despite the best efforts of all of the anti-smoking organizations in the past 20 years cigarette sales have

you to increase and set records up until the last year or two when the doubling of the federal excise tax and tax increases in about a score of States made cigarette prices go to about a dollar pack in many areas and that combined with the recession we were in really put a dent in sales dropping sales last year I think by about 5% their rebounding this year as we thought they would be and if the Federal

tax goes back to 8 cents a pack next year's it's supposed to from 16 cents a pack sales might increase even even further would you like to respond to that question price the price the anti-smoking efforts I think that the what the American Cancer Society in particular has been very active for many years and anti smoking area a few years ago there was a very strong push among Physicians to stop smoking and there has been

very striking change in the number of Physicians and medical students is smoke when I started to medical school back in 1961 I suppose probably in my class 60 or 70% of the people smoked today I think probably in the freshman class and I happened to ask them last year I think it's something like 15 or 20 percent smoke so among Physicians you know there has been a considerable decrease in the incidence of smoking

okay back when you were getting ready to do or what teenage teenager are just out of school anyone years 21 years old well that leads me to the question about the Institute there are more and more teenagers and preteens agers taking up smoking now I've seen them but how does the Institute feel about that I know it's probably just something prea peer pressure maybe but well for the last 70 years as a matter of fact the percentage of teenagers smoking has been going down that's fine as far as we're concerned are

industry policy since long before any of today's teenagers were even born has been smokings an adult custom it's not for kids children teenagers young teens don't have the maturity of judgment that's necessary to make a decision about smoking just as they don't have that same maturity that's necessary to decide a lot of things that are reserved for adults we've done quite a bit of advertising on this subject in National Consumer magazines trying to point out to parents

how we feel and why and that we think it's their responsibility to help their kids make decisions like this and I believe very shortly we're going to be seeing a lot more that the industry is going to be doing in this area because we take this responsibility very seriously just as we take our responsibility to fund health research very seriously I think we have some responsibilities there that we have been meeting fairy fairly clearly for

good number of years because we voluntarily for example not advertised in college and university Publications we have some voluntary restrictions on where our print advertising can appear and what kind of models can be used don't use celebrities or for example or sports figures because of that same appeal to youth sort of thing we volunteered

go off radio and television in 1969 because of radio and TV is unique appeal to young people so we've taken some very consistent positions on this over the years we've tried to make it very clear that we want to sell cigarettes to adults who want to buy cigarettes and not to kids okay speaking of your advertising what are your Trends in advertising now you just more what magazine since you're not on television anymore what what are your specific aims as far as advertising well the the aim of cigarette advertising

as with a lot of products that have been around for a long time is to try to get people who already use the product to maintain their brand loyalty or to switch their brand loyalty cigarette advertising doesn't appeal to non-smokers it appeals to people who already use the product people who already smoked trying to get them to change their brand or maintain their loyalty to their present brand I remember some studies that have been done in Europe on teenagers who smoke and they found that

at the most popular brands among teen smokers in Europe are the least advertised Brands and that's I think the same kind of trans you probably find in many other countries the Cancer Society does quite a bit of anti-smoking advertisement to what are your specific aims you have any pin areas pinpointed to for your advertising that well I think that obviously

the philosophy and any educational program is to reach people at as young an age as possible you know the Communists I guess are the masters of this that if you give them the child they don't worry about the adults now I think the Cancer Society does go into schools and try to present their opinions and and the facts as they see them to the young people but you know I was under the impression that teenagers weren't even supposed to buy the back is that what is the law of regarding

Ellen cigarettes to various vary state by state in Most states it's 18 in one state that I'm aware of at 16 but one or two states have it older than that's very difficult law to enforce and most people who sell cigarettes over-the-counter may not really be aware that the law is on the books and then it's serious to be informed but it seems to me know if you were really serious about trying to prevent teenagers from smoking that

tobacco industry could at least control the people that are selling the cigarettes we don't have any control over them well you deliver the control government we can't control retailers we don't own them we own the product which we then sell to the retailer or the wholesaler well the fact that the law was established in the first place whose authority is it to enforce it I suppose it would have to be your local police or the shore of the Sheriff's Office and they've got an awful lot of things to do

as priority items before they get around to trying to NAB somebody who by Design or otherwise sell cigarettes to a kid but I'm bothered by the fact that I think that a child can walk into any place in town and buy cigarettes and walk out smoking they can't you know we can give lip service to that idea well we're against teenagers having this opportunity but yet they have it without any question and so I think that something needs to be done with regard to that you know if someone's 40 years old and they want to smoke cigarettes you know
that's that's their business as far as I'm concerned as long as it doesn't interfere with me or my activities I think that as a responsible physician is my

social role to tell them what I think about smoking but I am not going to go around and grab people cigarettes and throw them down and stop them although I know a few doctors that will go that far beyond one we bounced around a time I have two more questions here the fact that the government recently completed a very intensive study on heart disease and found it to be the number one killer in our in our country if this is true how far behind is cancer

do I have any well you know you can look at different numbers if you lump all heart diseases together you can probably say that this number one if you break out hypertension and arteriosclerosis heart disease are hardening of the arteries cancer is usually listed as the second or third killer in the country and the most common cancer to cause death is cancer of the lung which we think that 80% is caused by smoking

okay we one more question for you mr. Merriman we know that cancer research is an ongoing process I'm sure what about research on Tobacco very quickly to what extent are you researching tobacco use well obviously each of the companies has their own research and development departments which research the possibility of new products you see new products come on the market all the time low tar and nicotine cigarettes are perhaps the best example of that they now have about 50 percent of the market because

something with the industry thought consumers wanted and they tried to fill that desire on the part of consumers to purchase that product okay gentleman I sure appreciate you being with us tonight and we certainly appreciate all of you for joining us again on the Rock now thank you for watching good night
thank you for joining us this evening right and let us know what you want to see on Little Rock now
